page.title: 01HARRAY
page.content: This area of Harray consists, on the east side, of moorland hills rising to 200 metres. These are used extensively for peat cutting. On the west side the land slopes down to level ground which is intensively farmed with sheep and cattle. Running east-west through the middle of the area is the "Lyde Road" (The lyde being the gap in the hills between Harray and Rendall). Most of the farms are off this road, many of them being small holdings. The whole area is sparsely populated. In the N.W. corner is Corrisall farm, this is a museum of farming life and implements during the 18th Century.
